interactions.content:
#### Section 1: Invisible worlds
Materials and phenomena that occur on the nanoscale are, almost by
definition, too small for the human visual sense. Nevertheless, we
really do know their shapes, sizes, and compositions. To obtain this
information, we rely on techniques of **characterization**. Namely, on
the two closely related areas of **spectroscopy** and *imaging*.
Spectroscopy is the processes by which matter is bombarded with some
type of particle or radiation, and the particles that are scattered,
transmitted, or re-emitted are analyzed for clues about the structure.
Imaging techniques use a similar paradigm, but the end goal is not to
produce a quantitative spectrum but a visual image for processing (often
by the human brain). There are many modalities which combine
spectroscopy and imaging in a single instrument. For a video primer to
this chapter, visit 
>>>video(https://youtu.be/N18UhNQmI8o)

One of the things that differentiates science from everyday rational
behavior is that science needs special tools to overcome the limits of
human senses. We can only learn so much about the world from our senses
of sight, smell, hearing, touch, and taste. While we can determine some
things about the structure and properties of matter from our five basic
senses, we need to correlate these observations to information gleaned
from other tools. Nowhere is the augmentation of human senses more
necessary than in nanoengineering, where everything is way too small to
see with even the most powerful optical microscopes. For example, a
nanoparticle or quantum dot might have a diameter of 5 nm, but the
smallest wavelength of light that can be detected by the human eye is
about 400 nm, which corresponds to violet light. So, we are blind to
nanomaterials. That's why we can't see viruses billowing out of people's
mouths and noses, and it's also why we can't see the intricate details
of a computer microprocessor at the level of the transistor, even under
the highest possible magnification with a conventional microscope.

Thus, there is a conundrum posed by the diffraction limit of light. The
way to circumvent this problem is to use particles other than visible
photons, such as electrons, ultraviolet rays, X-rays, or even helium
nuclei. These approaches are analogous to optical microscopy in that
they use wavelike particles to interact with matter, and the image is
created from the ways in which light is absorbed or scattered from the
surface.

Such methods of obtaining images of nanoscale objects are not limited
only to modalities which shine---or blast---light or particles upon the
sample. The other major way in which information is collected about the
composition and structure of nanoscale materials is not by shining a
beam from a distance, but rather by physical contact or near-physical
contact, in methods that are akin not to the sense of vision but to the
sense of touch. Such approaches are referred to collectively as
"scanning probe" techniques. The feature that all scanning probe
instruments have in common is the use of a sharp object which scans
along a surface (like a vinyl or LP player). The tip can be used to plot
the topography, mechanical properties, conductivity, chemical
composition, or other properties of the surface. Finally, there are
techniques which use radiation not to generate images, but to probe the
structure of atoms, molecules, particles, and surfaces. These
spectroscopic modalities rely on the basic physics we have covered in
detail in Chapter 8, so we will begin here.
Do you have any questions?

#### Section 2: Spectroscopic characterization of nanomaterials
As we discussed in Chapter 8 on light-matter interactions, the
confinement of electrons in a nanomaterial gives rise to properties that
are related not only to the composition of the particle but to its
physical dimensions. Thus, it is possible to detect light that is
scattered, absorbed and scattered, or absorbed and re-emitted by the
process of fluorescence or phosphorescence. Alternatively, interrogation
with a high-energy beam of *something* triggers the ejection of some
other type of particle or radiation. The key insight in spectroscopy is
that the energies of these ejected or scattered waves or particles
correspond in a very specific way to the atoms, molecules, or materials
under interrogation.

When taking spectra from particles in solution, where solvent and solute
are totally mixed up, you get a single spectrum containing information
from everything in solution. However, when dealing with solid samples,
it is possible to obtain spectra from one region of the solid at a time.
Such spectra can be used to generate an image by plotting the spatially
resolved intensity of one or more signals. Such an image can be used on
its own or overlayed on top of an image using more conventional
techniques. This modality gives you information about the composition of
the structure and also the location of different atoms or bonding
arrangements between atoms in an image, and hence within an object. For
example, granite is an igneous rock composed of many different mineral
types. Putting a sample of granite in an electron microscope equipped
with an X-ray detector allows you to distinguish the location of the
minerals that make it up.

### 14.2.1. Nuclear magnetic resonance, NMR

Subatomic particles like electrons, protons, and neutrons have a
property known as spin. Remember from high school chemistry, you drew
"up" and "down" arrows when populating atomic orbitals with pairs of
electrons (one up, one down)? That notation was supposed to represent
**spin**. It is a property that allows twice as many electrons to occupy
the same orbital without creating huge repulsive forces by the Pauli
exclusion principle.[^14.2.1] You may remember that when constructing the
orbital energies like 1$s^2$, 2$s^2$, 2$p^6$, and so on, the electrons
are paired antiparallel in their respective orbitals or energy levels.
When spins are unpaired, the particle exhibits magnetic activity.

The concept of spin extends to other subatomic particles as well. For
example, when the nucleus of an atom has an odd number of protons and
neutrons---e.g., $^1$H or $^{13}$C---the nucleus itself can be oriented
in a magnetic field. In fact, it can be thought of as a little bar
magnet with a north and south pole. This magnetically active arrangement
can be exploited to learn something about the chemical environment of
the atom.

The technique for molecular structure determination by exploiting this
inherent magnetism of odd-numbered nuclei is called **nuclear magnetic
resonance (NMR)**. In NMR, a dilute solution of a molecule of interest
is placed inside a strong electromagnet cooled by liquid helium. This
electromagnet aligns all of the magnetic moments in a single direction.
Once aligned, a radio-frequency electromagnetic pulse can be applied.
Some of this radiation is absorbed by the nuclei, which flips the spin
from one orientation to another. As the magnetic moment goes back into
alignment with the field, some energy is released in the form of EM
radiation. This radio-frequency energy is transformed into a spectrum.
The spectrum that is produced gives information on the electromagnetic
environment of the magnetically active nuclei. For example, a hydrogen
atom, which has a total spin of one half because it has an odd number of
nucleons (i.e., a single proton), will resonate at a different frequency
depending on its chemical environment. In fact, $^1$HNMR is by far the
most useful and popular kind of NMR spectroscopy. For many organic
molecules, it is not necessary to use any other spectroscopic technique
to discern the structure.

$^1H$NMR derives its usefulness from the fact that every hydrogen atom
has a different resonant energy depending on the density of electrons
surrounding it. Thus, it is usually possible to piece together the
entire structure based on the precise energy of every hydrogen atom in
the molecule. Moreover, the **chemical shift** of the hydrogen atom is
predictable based on a handful of simple rules. For example, if the
hydrogen atom is attached to an electronegative element like oxygen, the
signal will be *de-shielded* by a predictable amount; if the hydrogen
atom is connected to an electropositive element like silicon, the
resulting signal is said to be *shielded*, also by a predictable amount.
Shielded and de-shielded atoms nuclei can be easily resolved by NMR
spectroscopy, with the resolution increasing with the strength of the
magnetic field. The strength of the signal (the area under the curve, or
the *integral*) also corresponds to how many atoms of a particular type
are within a molecule.

To convert from the standard output of NMR software, where the signals
are given in parts per million (ppm) to frequency of the emitted signal
(and equivalently, energy), one uses the following formulae, equations
(14.1) and (14.2)

(Equation 14.1)
$$\delta_{\text{Hz}} = \delta_{\text{ppm}} \times \text{frequency}_{\text{MHz}}$$

(Equation 14.2) $$E = h \times \nu$$

where $\delta_{\text{Hz}}$ is the chemical shift in Hz,
$\delta_{\text{ppm}}$ is the chemical shift in ppm,
$\text{frequency}_{\text{MHz}}$ is the operating frequency of the NMR
spectrometer in MHz, $E$ is energy $h$ is Planck's constant, and $\nu$
is frequency in Hz.

The NMR spectrum can also give information as to the mutual arrangement
or location of atoms attached to molecules at different points. They do
this by *through bond* or *through space* **coupling**. There are many
excellent references on the collection and interpretation of NMR spectra
and we will not go into here. See Figure (14.1) below for a couple of
examples of molecules matched to spectra.

(Figure 14.1) 
>>>image(NMR.png.0)

### 14.2.2. Ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy, UV-vis

One of the most common forms of spectroscopy involves the use of
ultraviolet and visible wavelengths of light to probe electronic
transitions in the molecules or particles. Photons in the UV-vis range
tend to have energies commensurate with the band gaps of molecules,
particles, and surfaces. That is, absorption of photons that correspond
to the promotion of electrons from the valence band to the conduction
band (when talking about inorganic materials) or from the highest
occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular
orbital (LUMO) (when talking about molecules). Given that the energies
of photons absorbed correspond to the transitions of electrons between
energy levels, UV-vis spectroscopy is often called **electronic
absorption spectroscopy**. Figure (14.2) shows the key features of a
UV-vis spectrum.

(Figure 14.2) 
>>>image(UV-vis.png.0)

The UV-vis spectrum is usually plotted with absorption on the $y$-axis
as a function of either wavelength (in nm) or energy (in eV). The
convention used weirdly depends on who is plotting the data: chemists,
biologists, and some engineers tend to plot the absorption as a function
of wavelength, while physicists and other engineers plot it as a
function of energy. Since wavelength is inversely proportional to
energy, the plots appear as mirror images of each other.[^14.2.2] Note that
while the differences between energy levels correspond to discrete
photon energies, the absorption spectra nevertheless appear as smoothed
out curves, rather than lines. The broadening of the spectrum arises
first from the *density of states* below the valence band and above the
conduction band. Other effects that lead to broadening involve
perturbations of the energy levels caused by molecular collisions with
each other and with solvent molecules, formation of energy levels
spanning multiple molecules from supramolecular organization (e.g.,
crystallization), and fluctuations of the energetic levels due to
electrostatic (e.g., van der Waals) forces. Despite the broadness of the
absorption profile, it is common practice to take the onset of
absorption as corresponding to the lowest energy photon absorbable by
the system and thus equivalent to the band gap. Usually, one takes the
slope tangent to the beginning of the curve and extrapolates toward the
$x$-axis, as shown in Figure (14.2). The $x$-intercept is taken as the
band gap.

UV-vis spectroscopy can be used to measure effects beyond the bandgaps
of molecules and semiconductors. For example, the localized surface
plasmon resonances (LSPRs) of metallic nanoparticles often also lie in
the ultraviolet or visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. When
placed in solution, colloidal metallic nanoparticles such as nanowires,
nanocubes, and nanospheres absorb and scatter wavelengths of light that
depend on the shape of the nanoparticle and the atoms(s) of which it is
composed. Recall that anisotropic nanoparticles like wires will have
multiple LSPRs, one for each dimension (a spherical or cubic particle
would have only a single resonance). The smaller dimensions will
resonate at higher energies than the larger ones. Thus, in solution,
where the particles are spinning and tumbling around randomly, all of
the LSPRs will be visible at once. However, if one deposits such
structures on glass or silicon using shearing forces during the
deposition, it is possible to get the particles to line up. Such
deposited structures will exhibit **birefringence**---in which polarized
light will trigger the LSPRs unequally. By using light with different
polarizations, it is possible to tease out the energies of the LSPRs
along the different axes (Figure (14.3)).

(Figure 14.3) 
>>>image(LSPR.png.0)

Finally, we note that such absorption behavior arising from electronic
transitions and LSPRs are not strictly limited to the range of photons
in the UV-vis region. In fact, many kinds of semiconductor nanocrystals
absorb in the near-infraried (NIR), and plasmonic nanoparticles with
dimensions of more than a few hundred nanometers also resonate in this
range. Thus, the technique is often referred to as UV-vis-NIR.

### 14.2.3. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy, XPS

We have seen above how photons can affect transitions of electrons from
one band to another within a solid. However, with high enough incident
energies of photons, electrons can be completely ejected from the
surface of a material. This phenomenon is called the **photoelectric
effect** (Figure (14.4) and was the basis of Albert Einstein's sole
Nobel Prize.[^14.2.3] In this theory, the kinetic energy of an electron
ejected from the surface of a solid is given by

(Equation 14.3) $$E = h\nu - \phi$$

(Figure 14.4) 
>>>image(photoelectric.png.0)

where $E$ is the energy (kinetic energy, because the electron is
moving), $h$ and $\nu$ are Planck's constant and the frequency of the
incoming photon, and $\phi$ is the **work function** of the surface. The
work function is conceptually similar to the **ionization energy**.
However, the ionization energy refers to the energy required to extract
the outermost electron from an atom in the gas phase, whereas the work
function is the energy required to extract an electron from the surface
of a material made of many atoms. The work function is always less than
the ionization energy for individual atoms of the same element. In part,
this difference arises because of the strong electrostatic attraction of
an electron to an ion in the gas phase; in a solid, the positive charge
left behind can more or less freely delocalize. Moreover, for an atom in
the gas phase, the ionization energy is taken as the energy of an
electron in the outermost (highest energy) occupied orbital. In a solid
metal, the outermost electrons are involved in strong metallic bonding.
In metallic solids, the energy of the outermost electrons is increased
to a value called the **Fermi level**, which represents the average
energy of the conduction electrons. The Fermi level is sometimes called
the *electrochemical potential* of the electrons.

When a photon of an energy equal to or greater than the Fermi level of
the metal surface, an electron is ejected. The finding illustrates one
aspect of the nature of light, namely the relationship between energy
and intensity. Among other observations, Einstein noted that increasing
the brightness or intensity of the light does not increase the energy of
the ejected **photoelectrons**, but it does increase their number. This
insight into the energies of photoelectrons---namely that they are
quantized and always have the same energies---is the basis for elemental
analysis by a technique called **X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
(XPS)**.

In the traditional conception of measurements of the photoelectric
effect, the incident beam is in the ultraviolet or visible region of the
electromagnetic spectrum. Photons with wavelengths in this range can
knock loose electrons in the highest energy atomic orbitals, or at the
Fermi level of the metal. However, if a beam made of much higher energy
photons is used, such as a beam of X-rays, it is possible to penetrate
much deeper into the atomic structures. In XPS, a high-energy beam of
photons (X-rays, $\lambda$ = 0.834 nm, E = 1486 eV, from an aluminum
source) blasts the surface of the sample. The collisions cause many
electrons to be ejected. These electrons can originate from any
electronic energy level within the atom. Recall from your chemistry
class that these energy levels correspond to the levels of 1s, 2s, 3p,
and so on. The further inside the atom, toward the nucleus, the more
tightly held the electron, and thus the greater energy needed to eject
it. However, once the electron is ejected, it arrives at a detector with
*less* energy than those which were on the outside---i.e., higher
energy---of the atom. The reason is that it took a lot of energy to
dislodge the electron from the inner core, as implied by equation
(14.3).

Given that every atom of any element has exactly the same energies for
electrons, the energies of the electrons ejected create a spectrum akin
to a fingerprint. Thus, it is possible to determine the elemental
composition of a material, at least near the surface. (The technique
works for the first 10 atomic layers or so.) See Figure (14.5) for an
illustration of a typical XPS spectrum.

(Figure 14.5) 
>>>image(XPS.png.0)

### 14.2.4. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy

A related technique to XPS is **energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy
(EDS)**. The major difference, at least operationally, is that in XPS
the incident beam is an X-ray and the emitted beam is made of electrons;
in EDS, the incident beam is an electron beam whereas the emitted beam
is X-ray photons. In brief, an energetic beam of electrons strikes the
atoms that make up a material, see Figure (14.5). These energetic
collisions knock inner-shell electrons into free space. So far, EDS
sounds a lot like XPS. However, it is not the ejected electrons are
detected, but rather *the photons released when outer-shell electrons
fill in the holes left by ejected inner-shell electrons*. These photons
are generally in the X-ray region of the electromagnetic spectrum. As in
XPS, the spectrum of energies produced creates a pattern unique to each
atom, like a fingerprint.

The EDS process is generally performed inside of a scanning electron
microscope (SEM, described in detail in the next section). The beam
scanned across the sample to generate the image also triggers the
production of X-rays. Thus, the SEM equipped with an X-ray detector can
simultaneously perform the imaging and the elemental analysis. It is
thus possible to overlay an elemental map on top of an electron
micrograph (image). In this type of composite image, different elements
are indicated using different colors. Electron microscopy plus EDS
analysis is a powerful tool to examine nanomaterials and the nanoscale
structures of larger samples.

[^14.2.1]: Which says that particles having all the same properties cannot
    occupy exactly the same space---they *exclude* each other.

[^14.2.2]: Recall that one can convert between wavelength and energy using
    the conversion factor of 1240 eV nm. Simply take the quantity you
    have and divide it into the conversion factor to obtain the other
    quantity. Thus a photon with an energy of 2 eV has a wavelength of
    620 nm, and vice versa.

[^14.2.3]: Despite possibly more important---and unquestionably deeper---work
    in the realm of relativity theory.
Do you have any questions?
reading this after taking a little break from nano, can you provide me some key notes on this section?

Certainly! Here are some key notes on this section:

1. The chapter discusses various spectroscopic techniques used in nanoscience.

2. It covers Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), UV-visible spectroscopy, X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), and Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS).

3. NMR exploits the magnetic properties of certain nuclei to determine molecular structure.

4. UV-vis spectroscopy probes electronic transitions in molecules and particles.

5. XPS uses high-energy photons to eject electrons from a material's surface, allowing elemental analysis.

6. EDS uses an electron beam to generate characteristic X-rays from a sample, also enabling elemental analysis.

Would you like me to elaborate on any of these points?
could you give me some notes that are more in-depth?

Certainly. Here are some more in-depth notes:

1. NMR:
   - Exploits spin properties of nuclei like 1H and 13C
   - Uses strong magnetic fields and radio-frequency pulses
   - Chemical shifts reveal atomic environments
   - Useful for organic molecule structure determination

2. UV-vis spectroscopy:
   - Probes electronic transitions and band gaps
   - Can detect localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPRs)
   - Spectrum often plotted as absorption vs. wavelength or energy
   - Band gap determined from onset of absorption

3. XPS:
   - Based on photoelectric effect
   - Uses X-rays to eject electrons from surface atoms
   - Ejected electron energies are element-specific
   - Analyzes surface composition (top ~10 atomic layers)

4. EDS:
   - Electron beam causes inner-shell electron ejection
   - Detects X-rays emitted when outer electrons fill inner holes
   - Often combined with SEM for elemental mapping
   - Provides spatial distribution of elements in a sample

Would you like more details on any specific technique?
are these notes in chronological order in the book? im going to re read it to get some more info

Yes, these notes are in the same order as presented in the book section you're reading. The text covers:

1. NMR (Section 14.2.1)
2. UV-vis spectroscopy (Section 14.2.2)
3. XPS (Section 14.2.3)
4. EDS (Section 14.2.4)

Re-reading is a great idea to solidify your understanding. As you go through, feel free to ask about any specific points that need clarification.
can you simply explain the process of NMR

Certainly. Here's a simple explanation of NMR:

1. Place sample in strong magnetic field
2. Apply radio-frequency pulse
3. Nuclei absorb energy, changing spin orientation
4. Nuclei release energy as they realign
5. Detect released energy
6. Convert signal to spectrum
7. Analyze spectrum for molecular structure info

This process exploits magnetic properties of certain nuclei (like 1H, 13C) to gain insights into molecular structure. The chemical environment affects the energy released, allowing structure determination.
more like in a sentence form pls

Sure, here's a simplified explanation of NMR in sentence form:

NMR works by placing a sample in a strong magnetic field, applying radio waves to flip the spins of certain nuclei, then detecting the energy released as these nuclei realign. The resulting signal provides information about the chemical environment of the atoms, helping to determine the structure of molecules.

Is this explanation clearer? Let me know if you need any clarification.
what is HNMR

HNMR, or more precisely 1H NMR, is:

Proton Nuclear Magnetic Resonance spectroscopy. It specifically analyzes hydrogen atoms in molecules, providing detailed information about their chemical environment and helping determine molecular structure. It's the most common and useful type of NMR spectroscopy in organic chemistry.
okay im not understanding anything from the UV-vis section, could you give me some notes to help me understand

Certainly. Here are some key points to help you understand UV-vis spectroscopy:

1. It uses light in ultraviolet and visible ranges.
2. Measures absorption of light by molecules or particles.
3. Absorption relates to electronic transitions (e.g., HOMO to LUMO).
4. Spectrum shows absorption vs. wavelength or energy.
5. Can determine band gaps of materials.
6. Also useful for studying plasmonic nanoparticles.

The textbook explains these concepts in section 14.2.2. Would you like me to clarify any specific part?
as far as the whole section, give me some notes, I need some understanding of the figures

Sure, let's break down the UV-vis section including the figures:

1. Figure 14.2 shows a typical UV-vis spectrum:
   - X-axis: wavelength or energy
   - Y-axis: absorption
   - Band gap determined by extrapolating onset of absorption

2. Figure 14.3 illustrates LSPRs in nanoparticles:
   - Different shapes have different resonances
   - Anisotropic particles (like wires) have multiple LSPRs

3. UV-vis can measure:
   - Electronic transitions in molecules
   - Band gaps in semiconductors
   - Plasmonic resonances in metal nanoparticles

4. Spectrum broadening occurs due to various factors like molecular collisions

Does this help? Which parts would you like more explanation on?
okay now give me notes of like the specifics like any vocabulary in need to know

Certainly. Here are some key terms from the UV-vis section:

1. Electronic absorption spectroscopy: Another name for UV-vis
2. HOMO: Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital
3. LUMO: Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital
4. Band gap: Energy difference between valence and conduction bands
5. LSPR: Localized Surface Plasmon Resonance
6. Birefringence: Different absorption for different light polarizations
7. Density of states: Contributes to spectrum broadening

These terms are crucial for understanding UV-vis spectroscopy. The textbook explains each in section 14.2.2. Any specific term you'd like more details on?
what about something about x ray

Sure, let's focus on X-ray related concepts:

1. XPS: X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy
2. Photoelectric effect: Ejection of electrons by high-energy photons
3. Work function: Energy needed to remove an electron from a material's surface
4. Fermi level: Average energy of conduction electrons in a metal
5. EDS: Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy

These concepts are covered in sections 14.2.3 and 14.2.4 of the textbook. Would you like more details on any of these terms?
going back to the vocab, can you define them

Certainly. Here are brief definitions for the UV-vis vocabulary:

1. Electronic absorption spectroscopy: Technique measuring light absorption by electrons in molecules or materials.

2. HOMO: Highest energy occupied electron orbital in a molecule.

3. LUMO: Lowest energy unoccupied electron orbital in a molecule.

4. Band gap: Energy difference between valence and conduction bands in semiconductors.

5. LSPR: Collective oscillation of electrons in metallic nanoparticles when excited by light.

6. Birefringence: Material property where light experiences different refractive indices depending on polarization.

7. Density of states: Number of available energy states at each energy level in a material.

Would you like more explanation on any of these terms?
so diff nana particles have different LSPR?

Yes, that's correct:

Different nanoparticles have different LSPRs based on:
1. Their size
2. Their shape (spheres, rods, cubes, etc.)
3. The material they're made of

For example, gold nanospheres have different LSPR than gold nanorods. The textbook mentions this in the UV-vis section, particularly in relation to Figure 14.3. Would you like more details on how shape affects LSPR?
can you give me some notes about that last part of the XPS section

Certainly. Here are key notes about the last part of the XPS section:

1. XPS uses high-energy X-rays to eject electrons from atoms
2. Ejected electrons come from various energy levels (1s, 2s, 3p, etc.)
3. Inner electrons require more energy to eject, but have less kinetic energy when detected
4. Each element has a unique electron energy "fingerprint"
5. XPS can determine elemental composition of a material's surface
6. It works for approximately the first 10 atomic layers

Figure 14.5 illustrates a typical XPS spectrum. Does this summary help? Let me know if you need clarification on any point.
like that last paragraph more specifically

Ah, I see. The last paragraph of the XPS section focuses on:

1. Elemental composition determination
2. Surface sensitivity (about 10 atomic layers deep)
3. Unique "fingerprint" spectra for each element
4. Figure 14.5 showing a typical XPS spectrum

This part emphasizes how XPS is used for surface analysis and elemental identification. The textbook explains these concepts in more detail. Would you like me to elaborate on any specific point?
simply describe what is the process of XPS

The process of XPS can be simply described as:

1. High-energy X-rays hit the sample surface
2. X-rays cause electrons to be ejected from atoms
3. Ejected electrons' energies are measured
4. Energy values create a spectrum unique to each element
5. This spectrum is used to identify elements present in the sample

This process allows for surface elemental analysis of materials.

#### Section 1: Invisible worlds
Materials and phenomena that occur on the nanoscale are, almost by
definition, too small for the human visual sense. Nevertheless, we
really do know their shapes, sizes, and compositions. To obtain this

Spectroscopy is the processes by which matter is bombarded with some
type of particle or radiation, and the particles that are scattered,

Imaging techniques use a similar paradigm, but the end goal is not to
produce a quantitative spectrum but a visual image for processing (often
by the human brain). There are many modalities which combine
spectroscopy and imaging in a single instrument. For a video primer to
this chapter, visit 
>>>video(https://youtu.be/N18UhNQmI8o)

One of the things that differentiates science from everyday rational
behavior is that science needs special tools to overcome the limits of
human senses. We can only learn so much about the world from our senses
of sight, smell, hearing, touch, and taste. While we can determine some
things about the structure and properties of matter from our five basic

from other tools. Nowhere is the augmentation of human senses more
necessary than in nanoengineering, where everything is way too small to

nanoparticle or quantum dot might have a diameter of 5 nm, but the
smallest wavelength of light that can be detected by the human eye is

way to circumvent this problem is to use particles other than visible

they use wavelike particles to interact with matter, and the image is

instruments have in common is the use of a sharp object which scans

detail in Chapter 8, so we will begin here.
Do you have any questions?

#### Section 2: Spectroscopic characterization of nanomaterials
As we discussed in Chapter 8 on light-matter interactions, the
confinement of electrons in a nanomaterial gives rise to properties that
are related not only to the composition of the particle but to its
physical dimensions. Thus, it is possible to detect light that is
scattered, absorbed and scattered, or absorbed and re-emitted by the
process of fluorescence or phosphorescence. Alternatively, interrogation
with a high-energy beam of *something* triggers the ejection of some
other type of particle or radiation. The key insight in spectroscopy is
that the energies of these ejected or scattered waves or particles
correspond in a very specific way to the atoms, molecules, or materials
under interrogation.

When taking spectra from particles in solution, where solvent and solute
are totally mixed up, you get a single spectrum containing information
from everything in solution. However, when dealing with solid samples,
it is possible to obtain spectra from one region of the solid at a time.
Such spectra can be used to generate an image by plotting the spatially
resolved intensity of one or more signals. Such an image can be used on
its own or overlayed on top of an image using more conventional
techniques. This modality gives you information about the composition of
the structure and also the location of different atoms or bonding
arrangements between atoms in an image, and hence within an object. For
example, granite is an igneous rock composed of many different mineral
types. Putting a sample of granite in an electron microscope equipped
with an X-ray detector allows you to distinguish the location of the
minerals that make it up.

### 14.2.1. Nuclear magnetic resonance, NMR

Subatomic particles like electrons, protons, and neutrons have a
property known as spin. Remember from high school chemistry, you drew
"up" and "down" arrows when populating atomic orbitals with pairs of
electrons (one up, one down)? That notation was supposed to represent
**spin**. It is a property that allows twice as many electrons to occupy
the same orbital without creating huge repulsive forces by the Pauli
exclusion principle.[^14.2.1] You may remember that when constructing the
orbital energies like 1$s^2$, 2$s^2$, 2$p^6$, and so on, the electrons
are paired antiparallel in their respective orbitals or energy levels.
When spins are unpaired, the particle exhibits magnetic activity.

The concept of spin extends to other subatomic particles as well. For
example, when the nucleus of an atom has an odd number of protons and
neutrons---e.g., $^1$H or $^{13}$C---the nucleus itself can be oriented
in a magnetic field. In fact, it can be thought of as a little bar
magnet with a north and south pole. This magnetically active arrangement
can be exploited to learn something about the chemical environment of
the atom.

The technique for molecular structure determination by exploiting this
inherent magnetism of odd-numbered nuclei is called **nuclear magnetic
resonance (NMR)**. In NMR, a dilute solution of a molecule of interest
is placed inside a strong electromagnet cooled by liquid helium. This
electromagnet aligns all of the magnetic moments in a single direction.
Once aligned, a radio-frequency electromagnetic pulse can be applied.
Some of this radiation is absorbed by the nuclei, which flips the spin
from one orientation to another. As the magnetic moment goes back into
alignment with the field, some energy is released in the form of EM
radiation. This radio-frequency energy is transformed into a spectrum.
The spectrum that is produced gives information on the electromagnetic
environment of the magnetically active nuclei. For example, a hydrogen
atom, which has a total spin of one half because it has an odd number of
nucleons (i.e., a single proton), will resonate at a different frequency
depending on its chemical environment. In fact, $^1$HNMR is by far the
most useful and popular kind of NMR spectroscopy. For many organic
molecules, it is not necessary to use any other spectroscopic technique
to discern the structure.

$^1H$NMR derives its usefulness from the fact that every hydrogen atom
has a different resonant energy depending on the density of electrons
surrounding it. Thus, it is usually possible to piece together the
entire structure based on the precise energy of every hydrogen atom in
the molecule. Moreover, the **chemical shift** of the hydrogen atom is
predictable based on a handful of simple rules. For example, if the
hydrogen atom is attached to an electronegative element like oxygen, the
signal will be *de-shielded* by a predictable amount; if the hydrogen
atom is connected to an electropositive element like silicon, the
resulting signal is said to be *shielded*, also by a predictable amount.
Shielded and de-shielded atoms nuclei can be easily resolved by NMR
spectroscopy, with the resolution increasing with the strength of the
magnetic field. The strength of the signal (the area under the curve, or
the *integral*) also corresponds to how many atoms of a particular type
are within a molecule.

To convert from the standard output of NMR software, where the signals
are given in parts per million (ppm) to frequency of the emitted signal
(and equivalently, energy), one uses the following formulae, equations
(14.1) and (14.2)

(Equation 14.1)
$$\delta_{\text{Hz}} = \delta_{\text{ppm}} \times \text{frequency}_{\text{MHz}}$$

(Equation 14.2) $$E = h \times \nu$$

where $\delta_{\text{Hz}}$ is the chemical shift in Hz,
$\delta_{\text{ppm}}$ is the chemical shift in ppm,
$\text{frequency}_{\text{MHz}}$ is the operating frequency of the NMR
spectrometer in MHz, $E$ is energy $h$ is Planck's constant, and $\nu$
is frequency in Hz.

The NMR spectrum can also give information as to the mutual arrangement
or location of atoms attached to molecules at different points. They do
this by *through bond* or *through space* **coupling**. There are many
excellent references on the collection and interpretation of NMR spectra
and we will not go into here. See Figure (14.1) below for a couple of
examples of molecules matched to spectra.

(Figure 14.1) 
>>>image(NMR.png.0)

### 14.2.2. Ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy, UV-vis

One of the most common forms of spectroscopy involves the use of
ultraviolet and visible wavelengths of light to probe electronic
transitions in the molecules or particles. Photons in the UV-vis range
tend to have energies commensurate with the band gaps of molecules,
particles, and surfaces. That is, absorption of photons that correspond
to the promotion of electrons from the valence band to the conduction
band (when talking about inorganic materials) or from the highest
occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular
orbital (LUMO) (when talking about molecules). Given that the energies
of photons absorbed correspond to the transitions of electrons between
energy levels, UV-vis spectroscopy is often called **electronic
absorption spectroscopy**. Figure (14.2) shows the key features of a
UV-vis spectrum.

(Figure 14.2) 
>>>image(UV-vis.png.0)

The UV-vis spectrum is usually plotted with absorption on the $y$-axis
as a function of either wavelength (in nm) or energy (in eV). The
convention used weirdly depends on who is plotting the data: chemists,
biologists, and some engineers tend to plot the absorption as a function
of wavelength, while physicists and other engineers plot it as a
function of energy. Since wavelength is inversely proportional to
energy, the plots appear as mirror images of each other.[^14.2.2] Note that
while the differences between energy levels correspond to discrete
photon energies, the absorption spectra nevertheless appear as smoothed
out curves, rather than lines. The broadening of the spectrum arises
first from the *density of states* below the valence band and above the
conduction band. Other effects that lead to broadening involve
perturbations of the energy levels caused by molecular collisions with
each other and with solvent molecules, formation of energy levels
spanning multiple molecules from supramolecular organization (e.g.,
crystallization), and fluctuations of the energetic levels due to
electrostatic (e.g., van der Waals) forces. Despite the broadness of the
absorption profile, it is common practice to take the onset of
absorption as corresponding to the lowest energy photon absorbable by
the system and thus equivalent to the band gap. Usually, one takes the
slope tangent to the beginning of the curve and extrapolates toward the
$x$-axis, as shown in Figure (14.2). The $x$-intercept is taken as the
band gap.

UV-vis spectroscopy can be used to measure effects beyond the bandgaps
of molecules and semiconductors. For example, the localized surface
plasmon resonances (LSPRs) of metallic nanoparticles often also lie in
the ultraviolet or visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. When
placed in solution, colloidal metallic nanoparticles such as nanowires,
nanocubes, and nanospheres absorb and scatter wavelengths of light that
depend on the shape of the nanoparticle and the atoms(s) of which it is
composed. Recall that anisotropic nanoparticles like wires will have
multiple LSPRs, one for each dimension (a spherical or cubic particle
would have only a single resonance). The smaller dimensions will
resonate at higher energies than the larger ones. Thus, in solution,
where the particles are spinning and tumbling around randomly, all of
the LSPRs will be visible at once. However, if one deposits such
structures on glass or silicon using shearing forces during the
deposition, it is possible to get the particles to line up. Such
deposited structures will exhibit **birefringence**---in which polarized
light will trigger the LSPRs unequally. By using light with different
polarizations, it is possible to tease out the energies of the LSPRs
along the different axes (Figure (14.3)).

(Figure 14.3) 
>>>image(LSPR.png.0)

Finally, we note that such absorption behavior arising from electronic
transitions and LSPRs are not strictly limited to the range of photons
in the UV-vis region. In fact, many kinds of semiconductor nanocrystals
absorb in the near-infraried (NIR), and plasmonic nanoparticles with
dimensions of more than a few hundred nanometers also resonate in this
range. Thus, the technique is often referred to as UV-vis-NIR.

### 14.2.3. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy, XPS

We have seen above how photons can affect transitions of electrons from
one band to another within a solid. However, with high enough incident
energies of photons, electrons can be completely ejected from the
surface of a material. This phenomenon is called the **photoelectric
effect** (Figure (14.4) and was the basis of Albert Einstein's sole
Nobel Prize.[^14.2.3] In this theory, the kinetic energy of an electron
ejected from the surface of a solid is given by

(Equation 14.3) $$E = h\nu - \phi$$

(Figure 14.4) 
>>>image(photoelectric.png.0)

where $E$ is the energy (kinetic energy, because the electron is
moving), $h$ and $\nu$ are Planck's constant and the frequency of the
incoming photon, and $\phi$ is the **work function** of the surface. The
work function is conceptually similar to the **ionization energy**.
However, the ionization energy refers to the energy required to extract
the outermost electron from an atom in the gas phase, whereas the work
function is the energy required to extract an electron from the surface
of a material made of many atoms. The work function is always less than
the ionization energy for individual atoms of the same element. In part,
this difference arises because of the strong electrostatic attraction of
an electron to an ion in the gas phase; in a solid, the positive charge
left behind can more or less freely delocalize. Moreover, for an atom in
the gas phase, the ionization energy is taken as the energy of an
electron in the outermost (highest energy) occupied orbital. In a solid
metal, the outermost electrons are involved in strong metallic bonding.
In metallic solids, the energy of the outermost electrons is increased
to a value called the **Fermi level**, which represents the average
energy of the conduction electrons. The Fermi level is sometimes called
the *electrochemical potential* of the electrons.

When a photon of an energy equal to or greater than the Fermi level of
the metal surface, an electron is ejected. The finding illustrates one
aspect of the nature of light, namely the relationship between energy
and intensity. Among other observations, Einstein noted that increasing
the brightness or intensity of the light does not increase the energy of
the ejected **photoelectrons**, but it does increase their number. This
insight into the energies of photoelectrons---namely that they are
quantized and always have the same energies---is the basis for elemental
analysis by a technique called **X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
(XPS)**.

In the traditional conception of measurements of the photoelectric
effect, the incident beam is in the ultraviolet or visible region of the
electromagnetic spectrum. Photons with wavelengths in this range can
knock loose electrons in the highest energy atomic orbitals, or at the
Fermi level of the metal. However, if a beam made of much higher energy
photons is used, such as a beam of X-rays, it is possible to penetrate
much deeper into the atomic structures. In XPS, a high-energy beam of
photons (X-rays, $\lambda$ = 0.834 nm, E = 1486 eV, from an aluminum
source) blasts the surface of the sample. The collisions cause many
electrons to be ejected. These electrons can originate from any
electronic energy level within the atom. Recall from your chemistry
class that these energy levels correspond to the levels of 1s, 2s, 3p,
and so on. The further inside the atom, toward the nucleus, the more
tightly held the electron, and thus the greater energy needed to eject
it. However, once the electron is ejected, it arrives at a detector with
*less* energy than those which were on the outside---i.e., higher
energy---of the atom. The reason is that it took a lot of energy to
dislodge the electron from the inner core, as implied by equation
(14.3).

Given that every atom of any element has exactly the same energies for
electrons, the energies of the electrons ejected create a spectrum akin
to a fingerprint. Thus, it is possible to determine the elemental
composition of a material, at least near the surface. (The technique
works for the first 10 atomic layers or so.) See Figure (14.5) for an
illustration of a typical XPS spectrum.

(Figure 14.5) 
>>>image(XPS.png.0)

### 14.2.4. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy

A related technique to XPS is **energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy
(EDS)**. The major difference, at least operationally, is that in XPS
the incident beam is an X-ray and the emitted beam is made of electrons;
in EDS, the incident beam is an electron beam whereas the emitted beam
is X-ray photons. In brief, an energetic beam of electrons strikes the
atoms that make up a material, see Figure (14.5). These energetic
collisions knock inner-shell electrons into free space. So far, EDS
sounds a lot like XPS. However, it is not the ejected electrons are
detected, but rather *the photons released when outer-shell electrons
fill in the holes left by ejected inner-shell electrons*. These photons
are generally in the X-ray region of the electromagnetic spectrum. As in
XPS, the spectrum of energies produced creates a pattern unique to each
atom, like a fingerprint.

The EDS process is generally performed inside of a scanning electron
microscope (SEM, described in detail in the next section). The beam
scanned across the sample to generate the image also triggers the
production of X-rays. Thus, the SEM equipped with an X-ray detector can
simultaneously perform the imaging and the elemental analysis. It is
thus possible to overlay an elemental map on top of an electron
micrograph (image). In this type of composite image, different elements
are indicated using different colors. Electron microscopy plus EDS
analysis is a powerful tool to examine nanomaterials and the nanoscale
structures of larger samples.

[^14.2.1]: Which says that particles having all the same properties cannot
    occupy exactly the same space---they *exclude* each other.

[^14.2.2]: Recall that one can convert between wavelength and energy using
    the conversion factor of 1240 eV nm. Simply take the quantity you
    have and divide it into the conversion factor to obtain the other
    quantity. Thus a photon with an energy of 2 eV has a wavelength of
    620 nm, and vice versa.

[^14.2.3]: Despite possibly more important---and unquestionably deeper---work
    in the realm of relativity theory.
Do you have any questions?
can you simplify that last part of when it explained the EDS process, please

Certainly! Let's focus on the last part about EDS. Here's a simplified explanation:

1. EDS is often done inside a scanning electron microscope (SEM).
2. The electron beam used for imaging also triggers X-ray production.
3. An X-ray detector in the SEM can analyze these X-rays.
4. This allows for simultaneous imaging and elemental analysis.
5. The result can be a color-coded map showing different elements on the SEM image.
